--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> okily dokily. I poked through the big paper, and it said what you 
just
> said, but I'm still stuck on the competing conventions problem. 
Your
> paper didn't present any opposing views to compare historical 
markers
> to. I'm still pretty new to the field, and I don't understand what 
kinds
> of alternatives exist. Is this a totally new approach, or is there 
some
> computationally intensive way of compareing traits/genes that 
might also
> be studied? 

The historical marking approach is unique and did not exist before 
NEAT.  It is hard to answer whether "alternatives" exist because 
there certainly are other methods that evolve topologies (of various 
things including neural networks) but they tend to do things that 
are not principled like cutting an arbitrary subgraph out of one 
topology and swapping it into another.  So such an approach might be 
considered an "alternative" although it does not really address the 
concern that we don't know which gene is which.  The short answer 
then is that yes NEAT is the first such method.

> I seems to me that two species that evolve totally
> independantly until their history seperates them to much, and they 
will
> not be afforded significant chance to combine. ( less than 1% as 
you say
> )
> If there were a function to evaluate the compatability of two 
networks (
> perhapse that were representative of a species ) than the 
likelyhood of
> succesfull interspecies crossovers would increase.
> so has this tree been barked up by plenty of other dogs, or is 
there
> something to play with here?

Well NEAT does have such a compatibility function, so I take your 
question to be whether you could somehow grade the probability of 
interspecies mating based on the compatibility of various networks, 
and the answer is yes.  It is possible to do anything you want based 
on the compatibility function, and using it as a basis for deciding 
which interspecies matings are tolerable is certainly feasible.

ken
